title: IS415 Group 4
text:
Welcome to ‚ÄúJB: The New Frontier?‚Äù


Our project aims to answer the following questions:

What factors influence the real estate market in Johor Bahru?
How are different housing types clustered?



Johor Bahru (JB) is generally seen as an accessible and low-cost shopping and dining haven for neighbouring Singaporeans. With housing prices in Singapore skyrocketing of late, many Singaporeans have turned to JB to seek cheaper housing, driving the local economy but also bringing with them unprecedented inflationary pressures.




The JB: The New Frontier? application is a Shiny web-based tool designed to assist users in analysing property prices and Points of Interest (POIs) within Johor Bahru, Malaysia, and the neighbouring suburb of Kulai to the north. By integrating geospatial data and interactive visualisations, the application enables users to explore property price patterns, assess their proximity to key amenities, and make well-informed decisions about property purchases. With features like base maps, hexagon grid analysis, and spatial statistical tools, users can identify districts of interest, uncover pricing trends, and evaluate properties based on type, price, and accessibility. This comprehensive platform ensures a data-driven approach to property investment in JB.




To enable non-specialists to use geospatial analytics to understand and predict real estate trends, empowering better investment decisions in Johor Bahru.







Interactive Maps: Visualise property prices and distribution using various mapping techniques, including base maps, hexagon grids, and local statistical analysis.
POI Mapping: Filter and analyse Point of Interests (POIs) by category to assess proximity factors influencing property prices.
Property Data Overview: Explore detailed property transaction data, including type, price, and location.
Geospatial Insights: Leverage tools like Local Moran and Local Gi for understanding spatial dependencies and identifying clusters.





Base Map Features: View property prices classified by methods and currency preferences, with additional property-specific information available via interactive clicks.
Hexagon Grid Analysis: Break down districts into smaller regions to analyse property density and price metrics (mean, median, maximum).
Spatial Statistics: Use Local Moran and Gi analyses to detect significant clusters and hotspots of property pricing trends.
Customisable Filters: Narrow down analysis to specific property types or regions of interest for focused insights.





District Comparison: Compare property prices and amenities across districts to evaluate potential purchase locations.
User-Friendly Interface: Intuitive navigation tabs to simplify the exploration of property and POI data.
Actionable Insights: Provide data-driven recommendations to help users make well-informed property purchase decisions.






The following datasets were used for this prototype:



Data
Description
Source
Processing method/tool used




Johor Bahru, Malaysia Mukim boundary data
Geographical boundary data for Mukims in Johor Bahru and Kulai
United Nations Humanitarian Data Exchange (from geoBoundaries)
Filtered away all districts except Johor Bahru and Kulai


Point of interest (POI) data
Nearby amenities, such as schools, parks, shopping malls and CIQ checkpoints, to properties
OpenStreetMap
OSM Overpass Turbo API was used to extract POI data for Johor Bahru and Kulai


Property transaction data, 2023-2024
Property transaction data for Johor Bahru and Kulai
Portal Pusat Maklumat Harta Tanah Negara - Department of Valuation and Property Services, Malaysia
Extract relevant data within Johor Bahru and Kulai, drop null values






During a townhall presentation on 18 November 2024, we received some feedback and recommendations by our peers and members of the public, such as the following:

‚ÄúApp takes a very long time to load‚Äù
‚ÄúWhen buying a property, I would have already considered roughly where I want to buy.‚Äù
‚ÄúComparing against the whole JB seems irrelevant‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúConfused on what the ‚Äòhedonic‚Äô part tell me‚Äù
‚ÄúAs a user/Singaporean, wouldn‚Äôt I be more interested in the price of property within a region than the factors affecting the price‚Äù -> questioning the relevance of ‚Äòhendonic pricing model‚Äô to our project objective


Based on the feedback given, we modified our application to be more user friendly and less complex, to achieve our objective of empowering non-specialists to make better investment decisions in Johor Bahru using geospatial analytics. The following are the changes made in response:

Allow user to filter by district (Mukim) and analyse the property trends [This addressed the concerns raised by test users on speed and relevance of application to our project objective]
Removed the Hendonic pricing model and focusing more on the explanatory analysis of Exploratory Spatial Data Analysis (EDSA), Local Indicators of Spatial Association (LISA) and Hot and Cold Spot Analysis. [To allow user to make use of the analysis for more informed decision when buying a property in JB]
Changes to the user interface of the application to make the application more user friendly, even for first-time and low technical proficiency users.

title: JB: The New Frontier?
text: Of late, housing prices in Singapore have been flying through the roof. Because of this, many Singaporeans who yearn for a private space of their own without breaking the bank have been snapping up properties in neighbouring Johor Bahru, Malaysia. How high will this drive property prices in the city, perhaps best known among Singaporeans as a cheap and easily accessible weekend shopping getaway? Compared to Singapore, what factors influence the JB property market? Where is each type of housing, catered to different income levels, clustered? And does it matter that JB‚Äôs suburbs lack reliable access to public transport? This project aims to find the answers to these lingering questions and more, through a geospatial analysis on the property market of Johor Bahru and its emerging next-door neighbour, Iskandar Puteri

title: JB: The New Frontier?
section: PP2. Issues the project will address
text:
PP2. Issues the project will address
The project will make it easy for interested researchers and casual observers, especially those from Singapore, to understand the factors influencing the property market in Johor Bahru and Iskandar Puteri.

title: JB: The New Frontier?
text: PP3. Relevant related work

title: JB: The New Frontier?
section: PP4. Approach team plans to take to solve the problem
text: PP4. Approach team plans to take to solve the problem

title: JB: The New Frontier?
text:
PP5. Early prototypes or storyboards
Home page of application





A user guide page to show usage examples and analysis results, providing an overview of the functionalities of the app.





A tab to navigate to the main fuctionalities, which includes:

KDE of amenities in study area
Hot/Cold spot analysis (to be determined)
Hedonic Pricing Model (to be determined)







pacman::p_load(sf, tmap, tidyverse)
malaysia_adm2 <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/myadm2", layer = "geoBoundaries-MYS-ADM2") %>% st_transform(4326)
malaysia_adm3 <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/myadm3", layer = "geoBoundaries-MYS-ADM3") %>% st_transform(4326)
tmap_mode('view')
tmap_options(check.and.fix = TRUE)
tm_shape(malaysia_adm2) + tm_polygons()
tm_shape(malaysia_adm3) + tm_polygons()
tmap_mode('plot')

title: JB: The New Frontier?
section: PP3. Approach team plans to take to solve the problem
text:
PP3. Approach team plans to take to solve the problem
The proposed outline of the project will be as follows:

Vanilla and Emerging Hot/cold spot analysis on average/median property values for each Mukim in Johor Bahru and Iskandar Puteri (Pulai)
KDE on selected amenity types (e.g.¬†schools, shopping malls, major transport nodes, commercial districts, industrial districts) in Johor Bahru using data scraped from OpenStreetMap
Building a hedonic pricing model for residential properties in Johor Bahru

title: JB: The New Frontier?
text:
PP4. Relevant related work
We take inspiration from an earlier example done by senior Megan Sim (2021), who created a similar hedonic pricing model for the public housing market in Singapore in 2021.

title: JB: The New Frontier?
text:
References
Sim, M. (2021, October 2025). Take-Home Exercise 3: Hedonic Pricing Models for Resale Prices of Public Housing in Singapore. https://is415-msty.netlify.app/posts/2021-10-25-take-home-exercise-3/

title: About us
text:
We are a group of students from Singapore Management University (SMU).
This website contains the entirety of our project, done by us with the guidance of our Professor for IS415: Geospatial Analytics and Applications.
Connect with us on LinkedIn (by clicking on our facesüòä):

  

This whole project wouldn‚Äôt be possible if not for the guidance and mentoring by the one and only Prof.¬†Kam Tin Seong.

title: IS415 Group 4
text: The JB: The New Frontier? application is a Shiny web-based tool designed to assist users in analysing property prices and Points of Interest (POIs) within Johor Bahru, Malaysia, and the neighbouring suburb of Kulai to the north. By integrating geospatial data and interactive visualisations, the application enables users to explore property price patterns, assess their proximity to key amenities, and make well-informed decisions about property purchases. With features like base maps, hexagon grid analysis, and spatial statistical tools, users can identify districts of interest, uncover pricing trends, and evaluate properties based on type, price, and accessibility. This comprehensive platform ensures a data-driven approach to property investment in JB.

title: IS415 Group 4
text:
During Townhall, where we showcased our application we received some comments and recommendations by our peers and member of the public, below are some of the concerns:

‚ÄúApp takes a very long time to load‚Äù
‚ÄúWhen buying a property, I would have already considered roughly where I want to buy. Comparing against the whole JB seems irrelevant.‚Äù
‚ÄúConfused on what the ‚Äòhedonic‚Äô part tell me‚Äù

Based on the feedback given, we modified our application to be more user friendly and not over complicate too much, to achieve our objective of empowering non-specialists to make better investment decisions in Johor Bahru using geospatial analytics. The following are the changes made in response:

Allow user to focus on district (Mukim) and analyse the property trends [This not only shorten the for the processing of the app, it also addressed the concern raised by a potential user]
Removed the Hendonic pricing model and focusing more on the explanatory analysis of Exploratory Spatial Data Analysis (EDSA), Local Indicators of Spatial Association (LISA) and Hot and Cold Spot Analysis. To allow user to make use of the analysis for more informed decision when buying a property in JB
Changes to the user interface of the application, making the application more user friendly, even for first-time low technical proficiency user.
